CatDescriptText: Cutline of images published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 28, 1949, pg. 5, reads: "Crestas Terrace Murder - The murder of 10-year-old Raymond Jones by Andy Temkowicz, 70-year-old hermit, was re-enacted on Tuesday in presence of County Detectives Sam Riddle and Charles Halloran. In the upper left, Crestas Terrace Police Officer D. A. Cook is standing where Raymond Jones stood when the killer came on scene.  Dorothy Anderson with back to camera, is standing on spot where the four youngster were roasting potatoes and from where the killer fired.  On the right, in same picture, is shown the heavy brush through which three white boys escaped.  Trapped between the killer and brush, Raymond had no avenue of escape except to drop 500 feet to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad tracks below.  Lower left: Mrs. Henry, grandmother of Harry, and Raymond Hall, and Calvin Taylor, companions of the Jones youngster.  They escaped through the brush.  Top right: Mrs. Vivian Jones, mother of the dead boy, is shown with four of the youngest of her remaining six children.  Lower right: Crestas Terrace playmates of Raymond Jones."  Portion of accompanying article by Dorothy Anderson reads: "High above the Monongahela river in a densely wooded primitive fairyland, police and civilian searchers found the body of 11-year-old Raymond Jones, Sunday  morning, lying where a 70-year-old hermit, Andy Temkowicz had tossed it after firing a fatal bullet through the youngster's head.  Today Temkowicz sits in his barred cell in the Allegheny County jail muttering: 'They rob me, the boys always rob me,' as his excuse for wantonly firing into the little group of youngsters picnicking in the woods he had come to regard as his own..."  "...Police reconstruction of the happening indicates that Raymond Jones, one of seven children of Mrs. Virginia Jones of Crestas Terrace, Harry Hall, 8, Raymond Hall, 13, and Calvin Taylor, 7, had gone on an impromptu potato-roast to the top of Stuckey's Woods hill. While roasting their potatoes, the children were startled to see Temkowicz brandishing a gun and cursing them after a silent approach through the heavily wooded area..."
TitMainTitle: Crestas Terrace police officer D. A. Cook, and Dorothy Anderson, standing on hillside crime scene of murder of Raymond Jones, Crestas Terrace
